title-group.article-title: Endoscopic-Assisted Repair of Extensor Hallucis Longus Tendon Rerupture

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Orthopaedics and Traumatology, North District Hospital, Hong Kong SAR, China

author-notes.corresp: Tun Hing Lui, Consultant, Department of Orthopaedics and Traumatology, North District Hospital, 9 Po Kin Road, Sheung Shui, NT, Hong Kong SAR, China Email: luithderek@yahoo.co.uk

body.p: Level of Evidence: V, expert opinion.

Injury to the extensor hallucis longus (EHL) tendon is infrequent, and only a small number of case reports and series have been reported.1 The current standard care of acute EHL tendon laceration is still primary surgical repair,1,4,7,18,19 with reports showing fair to good outcomes, despite early literature that published conflicting treatment recommendations.5 However, in neglected EHL tendon laceration cases or in case of rerupture after primary repair, tendon retraction can pose a significant intraoperative challenge. In addition, these wounds are accompanied with significant scar formation, and this further prevents direct repair of the tendon ends, requiring large incisions to identify the remaining tendon and restore tendon structure with grafting.17,22 We describe a technique of endoscopic-assisted tendon repair to deal with delayed EHL rupture, which was at least 4 weeks after the injury. This has the advantage of minimally invasive surgery with better cosmesis as only 2 stab incisions are needed for the entire procedure. Moreover, the integrity of the extensor retinacula was preserved.

sec.title: Description of Technique
sec.p: The procedure is performed in a supine position, and a pneumatic thigh tourniquet is applied. No arthroscopic pump is used. The distal EHL tendon stump can be palpated, and a 5-mm distal portal wound is made 1 cm distal to the stump and medial to the tendon. Extensor hallucis longus tendoscopy is performed with a 30-degree 2.7-mm arthroscope. The distal stump is usually easily identified and the surrounding scar tissue is debrided. The proximal EHL tendon is retracted proximally with loss of tension and cannot be palpated easily. The tibialis anterior tendon can be used as a landmark to identify the proximal EHL tendon stump as it is at the lateral side of the tibialis anterior tendon. The EHL tendon is then traced distally to identify the proximal stump. A 5-mm proximal portal wound is made just proximal and medial to the proximal stump. The portal wounds are a bit larger than that required for the passage of the instruments to allow the saline to drain out. This can minimize the effect of fluid extravasation into the dorsal aspect of the foot. The proximal stump is freed from the surrounding scar tissue with an arthroscopic shaver through the proximal portal (Figure 1). The tenolysis should be started at the medial and dorsal sides of the proximal stump and then the lateral and plantar sides of the stump. The shaver ends should be kept toward the tendon under arthroscopic visualization during the tenolysis of the lateral and plantar sides of the stump. The suction should be kept to a minimum. These precautions can minimize the risk of injury to the neurovascular bundle. The proximal and distal stumps are pulled from the proximal and distal wounds, respectively. Both stump ends are sutured with No. 2 Ethibond (Ethicon, Somerville, NJ) by the Krackow locking suture technique. The stumps can be pulled toward each other outside the wound to restore the neutral position of the hallux. If the stumps do not touch each other, tendon grafting is indicated. The limbs of the sutures are pulled into the opposite portal wounds under the extensor retinacula under arthroscopic guidance and are sutured to the opposite stumps (Figure 2). The stitches are tied under tension to keep the hallux in a slightly dorsiflexed position with the ankle in neutral position (Figure 3). Postoperatively, the patient is put in a short leg cast with toe platform and advised to be nonweightbearing for 3 weeks and then weightbearing walking with wooden base shoes. Active big toe dorsiflexion is started 4 weeks after the operation.

caption.p: (A) Extensor hallucis longus (EHL) tendoscopy with proximal and distal portals. (B) Arthroscopic view through the distal portal. (C) Arthroscopic view through the distal portal. The tibialis anterior tendon is first identified and the proximal EHL tendon segment can be seen on the lateral side of the tibialis anterior tendon. (D) The EHL tendon is then traced distally to identify the proximal tendon stump end. a, Distal EHL tendon stump; b, inferior extensor retinaculum; c, EHL tendon; d, tibialis anterior tendon; e, superior extensor retinaculum; f, proximal EHL tendon stump.

(A) The proximal and distal stumps are pulled from the proximal and distal wounds, respectively. Both stump ends are sutured with No. 2 Ethibond (Ethicon, Somerville, NJ) by the Krackow locking suture technique. (B) A small suction tip is passed underneath the extensor retinacula from the distal to the proximal portal wounds under arthroscopic guidance. (C) The suture limbs of the proximal tendon stump are passed to the distal portal through the suction tip with suction applied. (D) The stumps are pulled into the portal wounds again and the limbs of the sutures are sutured to the opposite stumps. The stumps are then pushed into the wounds before the suture limbs are tensioned.

(A) The stitches are tied under tension to keep the hallux in a slightly dorsiflexed position with the ankle in neutral position. (B) Drawing to show the final construct. The other suture was not shown for simplicity. (C, D) The hallux is kept in position after the repair and only 2 small surgical wounds are needed.

sec.p: This procedure has been performed in 4 patients. Three of them had rerupture of the EHL tendon after primary repair, and the fourth patient had the EHL laceration missed initially. The average time lapse between endoscopic repair and the injury was 4.8 weeks (range, 4-6 weeks). No neurological complication or rerupture of the tendon was encountered.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Laceration of the EHL tendon is the most common indication for primary repair of the tendon. However, rerupture of the tendon after primary repair is not rare. Various methods for delayed surgical repair of EHL have been described previously.2,6,17,22

Although dorsiflexion of the ankle may deliver a retracted proximal stump to the preexisting surgical wound during open exploration of the tendon rerupture, sometimes the proximal retracted stump may be scarred down and require extensive soft tissue dissection and tenolysis to mobilize the proximal stump. This will result in a larger scar and sometimes limit movement of the ankle if wound extension is necessary across the ankle joint. In addition, open exploration of the tendons at the level of the ankle joint requires release of the extensor retinacula, and this poses a risk of tendon bow stringing. Repair of the retinacula needs a prolonged period of immobilization, and tendon adhesions may occur.

Foot and ankle tendoscopy is gaining popularity and is employed to treat lesions in various tendons such as the posterior tibial tendon, peroneal tendons, flexor hallucis longus, and extensor hallucis longus.2,3,5-17,20-22 In a delayed EHL rupture case, the role of tendoscopy is to identify the retracted proximal stump and to perform tenolysis in a minimally invasive approach. With the aid of the arthroscopic technique, identification of the tendon stumps, tenolysis, and tendon retrieval and repair can be performed under arthroscopic visualization through 2 small wounds. This has the potential advantage of minimally invasive surgery, including better cosmetic result, less soft tissue trauma, and scar formation.
